DOC.HEAD: US Soldier Shot Panamanian With Unauthorized Weapon, Pentagon Says
Eds: INSERTS grafs 4-5: ``In Panama,'' with report of planes arriving in Panama
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. soldier used an unauthorized weapon when he shot a Panamanian police officer Monday, the Pentagon's spokesman said Tuesday, calling the incident ``very regrettable'' but saying it had to be considered in the context of a deteriorating situation. ``What you have is a very difficult atmosphere in Panama right now. It's very tense,'' spokesman Pete Williams told reporters. He said people there are afraid for their lives amid the tension that has followed two shooting incidents in recent days. In Panama, according to NBC News, C-141 transports landed at Howard Air Base at 10-minute intervals throughout the afternoon. These planes are the kind used to carry paratroopers in what the Army said was a readiness exercise for elements of the 82 Airborne Division at Fort Bragg, N.C., though it could not be determined whether the planes in fact came from Fort Bragg. A reporter driving through the base Tuesday evening saw at least 10 large transport planes of an undetermined type, an unusually large number, and six to eight helicopters instead of the usual three or four. At the Pentagon, Williams said that although the Army lieutenant was in an authorized area at the time of the shooting, he was in civilian clothes and was carrying a sidearm. Asked if the officer had been authorized to do so, Williams answered: ``I don't believe he was authorized to have a weapon.'' The spokesman said the officer was still being questioned about the incident, and he added, ``You have to go back to the climate in which it happened.'' The lieutenant ``says the Panamanian reached for a weapon,'' the spokesman said. At the time, U.S. forces were on alert following the fatal Saturday shooting of Marine 1st Lt. Robert Paz, 25, of Dallas, and the reported beating of a Navy couple who U.S. officials say witnessed the shooting. President Bush has refused to rule out military action against the government of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega in response to the Saturday shooting. Williams, who said the Army lieutenant was still in Panama, blamed the incident in part on Noriega's Friday declaration of a ``state of war'' with the United States. ``People fear for their lives in Panama right now,'' Williams said. At the State Department, spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said Noriega's irresponsible declaration of a state of war last week was followed only hours later by ``indiscriminate and unprovoked violence against Americans clearly increases tensions in Panama. ``We find the unwarranted use of violence against Americans by the Noriega regime unacceptable,'' she said. Williams said that U.S. forces in Panama ``are ever-vigilant. They are acutely aware of the events that are taking place around them.'' He said U.S. officials are ``proceeding with caution'' as the go about their duties, but he added: ``We remain concerned about the situation in Panama, it appears to be deteriorating.'' When asked about reports of preparations among the 18th Airborne Corps, the spokesman said the unit ``periodically conducts emergency readiness deployment exercises to evaluate the readiness of its units. ... Currently, elements of the 18th Airborne Corps are conducting emergency deployment readiness exercises.'' On Capitol Hill, Sen. Richard Lugar, R-Ind., called on Bush to issue an ultimatum to Noriega, telling him that continued anti-American agitation will not be tolerated. ``Noriega appears to be testing the parameters of American tolerance,'' said Lugar, a senior Republican member of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. ``We need to avoid the appearance of acquiescence that might embolden Noriega and lead to future American and Panamanian casualties.'' ``There are measured options, military and otherwise, that would inconvenience Noriega and they ought to be considered promptly in the wake of unacceptable activities of the Panamanian defense forces,'' Lugar said. Sen. Christopher Dodd, D-Conn, the chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee on Western Hemisphere affairs, said on NBC-TV that Bush was correct in avoiding talking about a possible military response to Noriega. ``I think the president's handling that question appropriately. ... To not say exactly what you're going to do is probably the right thing to do,'' Dodd said. The senator said that if the lives of U.S. citizens in Panama are jeopardized, or if the canal were threatened, those two situations ``would be two at least broad areas that would ... warrant at least further consideration of direct military intervention.''
